before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"bmvsp","text":"This is a step-by-step guide developed at PsychoLab to set up the software used to assess prepulse inhibition (PPI) of the acoustic startle reflex in mice or rats using the equipment acquired from Insight Equipamentos Ltda.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuod4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ceq0h","text":"Make sure that the speakers and ventilation of the apparatus are turned on;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4h4oj","text":"In our protocol, we did not use any light source inside the box;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"31k0q","text":"Read the entire protocol before starting.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"322u6","text":"The acoustic startle reflex is an automatic and involuntary response that occurs in humans and other animals when they are exposed to sudden and intense acoustic stimuli, such as loud noises. This response can be influenced by several factors, including the intensity and timing of the stimulus, the individual's state of alertness, and contextual factors. It can also be modulated by prior exposure to a weak prepulse shortly before the startling stimulus, a phenomenon known as prepulse inhibition (PPI). PPI reflects the brain's ability to filter out irrelevant or non-threatening sensory information, and is considered an important indicator of sensorimotor gating. In individuals with schizophrenia, both the startle response and prepulse inhibition are disrupted, which is believed to result from alterations in glutamatergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission. These deficits in sensorimotor gating may lead to sensory overload and the misinterpretation of sensory information. Here we describe a protocol to measure PPI in mice and rats using a startle chamber from Insight®️ (SP, Brazil).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"din1f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c85u0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

The execution of this protocol was aproved by CEUA-HCPA (approval no. 180498) and followed the relevant guidelines on care and use of laboratory animals and the Brazilian legislation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dif5u","text":"To create a new stimulus (hereby called \"Block\"), click on the \"add PPI\" icon, it is the second icon from left to right below the table, on the right side of the caption icon.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f69jf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8088","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3ked7","text":"A new block will be created and you will repeat the steps described in step 3, but this time, pulse and prepulse intensity should be set at the desired percentage according to your protocol. For more information on how to set a pulse or prepulse stimulus follow the steps below;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":71,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"952jc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8m5nn","text":"For a prepulse stimulus, in addition to background noise, you will also set pure tone percentages in the prepulse period. Do not forget to adjust the decibel meter according to the range that you are configuring;  you will set background noise and prepulse period with pure tone;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":6,"length":17},{"style":"bold","offset":76,"length":22},{"style":"bold","offset":120,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8iu0s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fvhgh","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dnc6b","text":"For a pulse stimulus, you will set background noise and pulse period with white noise;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":6,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fubmr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4n6dd","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9ephd","text":"For a prepulse + pulse stimulus, background noise, pulse period and prepulse period should be set;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":6,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ah0um","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aab2g","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2jchl","text":"Do not forget to take notes of the percentages used - you can find the right percentage for each stimulus just once and then apply it to the rest of the combinations;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4jii","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehgn9","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bodap","text":"You should create as many stimuli as needed, so, for example: if your protocol has 15 unique combinations of stimuli, you should create 15 blocks of PPI and calibrate them individually. {"blocks":[{"key":"5ftt9","text":"To configure stimuli settings, go to the table and set the duration of each period in the first line according to your protocol. {"blocks":[{"key":"cfqa9","text":"Once all stimuli are created, click on the floppy disk icon on the far right below the table. Experiment identification window will open. The scale used by the equipment is number one. The data entered here will be exported in the results report, available at the end of each test. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7dkn0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"khu9","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1oukh","text":"Always take note of the identification number, just above the experiment identification headline. The equipment storages up to 100 subjects' data. If, for example, you are starting your test at ID 93 and will test ten subjects, the equipment will automatically count subsequent subjects in crescent order, but it would replace ID 100 three times since you have 10 subjects and only 7 data spots. In cases when ID spots are insufficient, you should reset ID count.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aan91","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28i44","text":"Resetting ID count will not erase previous data. To do that, click on \"Reports\" on the main screen. The data bank window will pop up.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18},{"style":"bold","offset":70,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2levo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"be0lg","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"btmcv","text":"Be aware that this action will not erase previous data, but can not be undone. If you are sure, click on the penultimate icon on the top bar and the ID count will be reset.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2hlmr","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1bh9e","text":"The data filling here works as a complement to better identify your subject, although we advise you to at least identify yourself (researcher) and the subject, it is not necessary to the test that you fill this part. When finished, click on the floppy disk icon on the left-up corner to save and exit the window. {"blocks":[{"key":"9l1t8","text":"Scale calibration is an important step to ensure that data collection of startle responses is accurate. First, remove the decibel meter from the scale if it is still inside the chamber. At the beginning of the test, you will click on the option \"No, scale calibration presents considerable errors. Repeat scale calibration process now\". ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"44kf3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dck7v","text":"   ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":1,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"640qb","text":"Follow the process shown in the new window. It is recommended to use clean and dry gloves when handling the 50-gram weight. The scale calibration weight can be found within the apparatus;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7i3r1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eflna","text":"After completing the process, check whether the scale accurately displays the weight of 50g and if it resets to zero when the weight is removed;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3qip","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e80ue","text":"You can calibrate the scale at the beginning of the tests and then watch carefully in every session if the measuring is consistently accurate (i.e, resetting to zero without fluctuations). If it is, you do not need to calibrate the scale again;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ln1b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dvllg","text":"After finishing scale calibration, you should click on \"Yes, current scale calibration is satisfactory. Execute the next step\".","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"92E56320E9C111ED85EC5D1B14D15A18","height":311,"id":393948,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","nestedSelector":null,"original_name":"3 (10).png","placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nay8bffm7.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nay6bffm7.jpg","webp_placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nay7bffm7.webp","webp_source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/nay5bffm7.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d2b8o","text":"Session configuration is where you will create stimuli presentation order, which will be exactly the same in all sessions. In the procedure blocks column, you will see the previously created blocks (stimuli) just above the \"Habituation with background noise on\" box. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21},{"style":"bold","offset":130,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3br54","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cktfo","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"tofe","text":"If you want the habituation period to have background noise on (standard background noise, not configurable) check the box below the first column. If you do not have a habituation period foreseen in your protocol or prefer silence, you should leave the box unchecked;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":15,"length":47}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brbo7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"l9j7","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a9p94","text":" To configure the session, you will transfer the blocks (stimuli) from the procedure blocks column to the execution session column. To do that, you can select the block(s) and press \"Export selected blocks\", which is the fourth icon below the first column. This will transfer blocks in the same order as they are seen in the first column. {"blocks":[{"key":"fcdjg","text":"Data will be presented as arbitrary units. Important outcomes to be analyzed are the reactivity (startle) to all pulse and prepulse intensities and then prepulse inhibition for each combination, calculated as follow:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4c8q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6tnlu","text":"For pulse and prepulse reactivity, use the mean value of each stimulus. For example, if pulse 100 dB was presented 10 times, you should use these 10 stimuli presentation values to discover pulse 100 dB reactivity value;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":43,"length":27},{"style":"bold","offset":202,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gljg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cr27l","text":"For prepulse inhibition for each combination, use  . For example, if you want to calculate the PPI percentage for prepulse 71 dB combined with pulse 100 dB (pp71p100), you would use (p100 - pp71p100)/p100 * 100;","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":182,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":50,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"arf38","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"73ho","text":"Finally, for % mean PPI, use the mean value of all %PPI calculated for each combination of stimulus.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"o8ht","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tex_formula","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"formula":"(pulse alone - prepulse + pulse) / pulse alone  * 100","guid":"9B1A75DAFA3411ED82030A58A9FEAC02","id":0}}}}
